content.description:
This crack/seam is the right most of the Lone Pine Tree cracks.  It is approached from the ledge off of the climber's trail on the east side of No Name Creek.  This route is generally toproped by the same anchors as

Lone Pine Tree Left

and

Direct

.  A thin crack/seam provides tenous holds and minimal gear.  A few RP placements may be worked out.  Ballsy lead/ solo, if your up for it!
content.protection: Not much; maybe some tiny swedges and RPs.

content.description:
This is the leftmost and easiest crack of the Lone Pine Tree climbs. It is the right-arching crack found on the same ledge as

Lone Pine Tree Direct

. Approach by the climbers trail off the maintainence road on the east side of No Name Creek.  Good jams with a few off width moves near the top bring you to the lone pine tree anchor.
content.protection: Standard granite rack (a larger piece or two wouldn't hurt).

content.description:
This route is on the face furthest left on the east side of No Name Creek.  It is down and to the left of the

Pink Face

.  It is the direct line up to a lone pine tree anchor (hence the inventive name) which is reached by an easy fifth class move off of the trail up to a spacious belay ledge.  The splitter line straight up from the ledge has some great thin hand crack moves.  Some insecure thin hands can make this route a challenge for gear placement;  I wouldn't recommend it for a first 5.10 lead.  Great afternoon sun exposure.
content.protection: Standard granite rack (it really eats up stoppers).

climbs.name: Guys with Guns
climbs.fa: unknown, surely climbed by someone long before

content.description:
Starting as for the other Lone Pine Tree wall routes, from the ledge, climb the corner on the right to a ledge from where you could step down and be at the base of the Pink Face. Instead, continue into the large chimney system where a two bolt anchor is on the right hand face.

If starting from the trail or main base area, as is standard and best, it's 100 feet to the anchor. Tie a knot in the end of your rope.

This is listed as "Right Corner" in the new 2016 guidebook.
content.protection: Standard rack plus a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Start as for the other Lone Pine Tree wall routes, and climb the corner on the right side of the wall.
